abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome for the Institutional Reform
            Credit for Rwanda was satisfactory, the sustainability was
            likely, the institutional development impact was
            substantial, the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the
            borrower performance was highly satisfactory. Lessons
            learned: The presence of a Poverty Reduction Strategy Paper
            (PRSP) underscores the Government of Rwanda (GoR's)
            strong commitment and ownership of the IRC. The adoption and
            institutionalization of the principle of Budget Program
            Priorities (BPPs) of the PRSP and the Medium Term
            Expenditure Framework (MTEF) constitute effective measures.
            Effective implementation and monitoring mechanisms for
            reform programs are those that are supported at the highest
            levels of a country's political hierarchy and civil
            service. Reforms carried out on a more comprehensive and
            multifaceted basis, are also more likely to have a greater
            impact and sustainability. To facilitate supervision of the
            development policy credit, it would be recommended to have a
            policy matrix or indicators of outputs and outcomes. The
            successful implementation of policy and institutional
            reforms requires adequate capacities in key areas.

6140446.trustfund:
TF026735-PHRD-RWANDA: INSTITUTIONAL
            REFORM CREDIT,TF029906-BNPP-POVERTY: MAINSTREAMING
            POVERTY IMPACT EVALUATION IN THE REGIONS,TF052699-TFESSD POVERTY WINDOW : POVERTY
            AND SOCIAL IMPACT ANALYSIS OF TEA FACTO

abstracts.cdata!:
The Institutional Reform Credit Project
            builds on the progress made in reforms under the preceding
            Economic Recovery Credit (ERC), and consolidates the
            benefits from those reforms. Despite de Government's
            continued commitments to reform, GDP growth remains at just
            under 3 percent per annum, a slow down that resulted from
            lower than expected agricultural output, and the current
            electricity shortage. The report outlines problems in public
            finance, and in the monetary policy, affecting the banking
            and financial sector. However, conditions for the release of
            the third tranche have been met, thus, in view of the
            overall performance and progress with the implementation of
            the program supported by the Credit, and in full compliance
            with the specific conditions of release in accordance to the
            Credit Agreement, availability of the third (floating)
            tranche is released.

5085636.trustfund:
TF026735-PHRD-RWANDA: INSTITUTIONAL
            REFORM CREDIT,TF052699-TFESSD POVERTY WINDOW : POVERTY
            AND SOCIAL IMPACT ANALYSIS OF TEA FACTO,TF029906-BNPP-POVERTY: MAINSTREAMING
            POVERTY IMPACT EVALUATION IN THE REGIONS
5085636.majtheme: Social protection and risk management,Human development

abstracts.cdata!:
The Institutional Reform Credit Project
            for Rwanda is a precursor to a Poverty Reduction Support
            Credit (PRSC) and provides quick disbursing finance to
            support the implementation of the Government's poverty
            reduction strategy as elaborated in the PRSP. Over the next
            three years, the Government intends to reinforce its poverty
            reduction efforts with public and institutional measures to
            strengthen the budget process, improve public sector
            capacity and governance, promote private sector investment,
            production and employment creation, and develop human
            resources. Theis project continues support for reform
            efforts provided by the Economic Recovery Credit (report no.
            P7292). This project's main components are public
            expenditure reform, including the strengthening of financial
            accountability, private sector development including the
            financial sector, and privatization of state-owned
            enterprises and human development including gender reforms.
            The Credit will be disbursed in three tranches. Expected
            benefits include: 1) improving public social and other key
            services; 2) increasing rural production and incomes through
            enhanced secrity of land tenure, improved incentives for
            producers of coffee and tea and a sustainable framework for
            distribution and market ing of agricultural inputs; 3)
            stimulating private sector activity; and 4) improving
            economic opportunities and incomes in order to reinforce
            efforts for national reconciliation.
